description: Clipping of omnibus. Formerly often spelt 'bus. The electrical sense is derived from figurative application of the automotive sense.

entries.meaning: (automotive) A motor vehicle for transporting large numbers of people along roads.
An electrical conductor or interface serving as a common connection for two or more circuits or components.
Part of a MIRV missile, having on-board motors used to deliver the warhead to a target.

verbs.description: bus (third-person singular simple present busses or buses, present participle bussing or busing, simple past and past participle bussed or bused)

entries.meaning: (transitive, automotive, transport) To transport via a motor bus.
(transitive, automotive, transport, chiefly US) To transport students to school, often to a more distant school for the purposes of achieving racial integration.
examples: But if you ask me to bus my children / I hope the cops take down your name

entries.meaning: (intransitive, automotive, transport) To travel by bus.
(transitive, US, food service) To clear meal remains from.
examples: He bussed tables as the restaurant emptied out.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, US, food service) To work at clearing the remains of meals from tables or counters; to work as a busboy.
examples: Heâ€™s been bussing for minimum wage.
